谁发明了饮水杯？ （www.reference.com）
杯子（en.wikipedia.org）
pos_context_src:
原始人或同性恋者，当他看到丛林的野兽时，他用舌头用舌头将水吹到他的嘴里。但是人很快意识到，与他猎杀，烹饪和偶尔试图繁殖的动物不同，他有手。可以组合在一起形成一个浅弯曲的碗的手，可以用来容纳少量饮用水 - 这是杯赛进化的下一个重要步骤，经过多年的其他身体部位（例如肚脐）进行了多年的痛苦实现。


最终，一个并不愚蠢的人出生了。形成一个粘土的圆柱体，他用一个开放式的末端使用了原始杯子，主要是在别人的对话中聆听门。然后有一天说船只与水接触。
饮酒杯的原始发明者不知道，因为在录制历史上，饮酒杯就存在。对于早期的培养，喝酒杯对于用杯状的手喝液体而言是一个巨大的改善。
杯子是使用杯子或脚固定液体的改进。自从录制历史上以来，几乎可以肯定地使用了它们，并在世界各地的考古遗址被发现。史前杯子有时是用贝壳制成的，并挖空了石头。[7]

question_en: How do ads follow me from my phone to my computer?
pos_context_title_en: Why Do Ads Follow Me Around the Internet? (askleo.com)
How Ads Follow You from Phone to Desktop to Tablet (www.technologyreview.com)
How Internet Ads Follow You Around (lifehacker.com)
pos_context_en:
It works like this:


1. You visit a shopping site, or a site that offers some kind of service. This site may or may not show ads, but they do include content from an advertising network.
2. The advertising network places a cookie on your computer. That cookie contains information to the effect of, “This computer was looking at X,” where X is the product or service offered by the site you’re visiting.
3. Eventually, you move on to another website — a site that also displays ads, and coincidentally uses the same advertising network as the site we started at.
4. That advertising network is given its own cookie back — the one that says, “This computer was looking at X” — and as a result, elects to show you ads for X.
Signing into Google or Facebook as well as websites and apps using those logins confirms which devices you own.
Facebook and Google can collect data on you even if you don’t have an account, by scooping up your friends’ phone contacts or by logging usual browser data.
question_src: 广告如何从手机到计算机关注我？
pos_context_title_src: 为什么广告在互联网上关注我？ （askleo.com）
广告如何从电话到台式机到平板电脑（www.technologyreview.com）如何关注您
互联网广告如何跟随您（LifeHacker.com）
pos_context_src:
它是这样的工作：


1。您访问购物网站或提供某种服务的网站。该站点可能会或可能不会显示广告，但它们确实包括广告网络的内容。
2。广告网络将cookie放在您的计算机上。该cookie包含了“这台计算机正在看x”的效果的信息，其中x是您访问的网站提供的产品或服务。
3。最终，您转到另一个网站 - 一个也显示广告的网站，并巧合地使用与我们启动的网站相同的广告网络。
4。该广告网络被赋予了自己的cookie，其中说：“这台计算机正在看x”  - 因此，选择向您展示X的广告。
使用这些登录名登录Google或Facebook以及网站和应用程序，请确认您拥有的设备。
Facebook和Google可以通过sc订出朋友的电​​话联系人或记录常规浏览器数据来收集您的数据。

question_en: Why are so many people choosing longboards over traditional skateboards these days? Are they easier to ride? What is the benefit?
pos_context_title_en: Longboard VS Skateboard – Pros, Cons, and Differences – BoardCoast (www.boardcoast.com)
Longboards Vs. Skateboards (www.redbull.com)
Longboard vs Skateboard – Similarities and Differences | SkateboardersHQ (www.skateboardershq.com)
pos_context_en:
Longboards are typically much longer and wider than skateboards. They also have different types of wheels. Longboards have large, soft wheels whereas skateboards have small, hard wheels. Longboards are also much more flexible and tend to be easier to ride for beginners.

The soft wheels on a longboard are great for riding, and rolling over cracks and small debris at high speeds, but they are bouncier than hard wheels. Typically you don’t want to use soft wheels when performing tricks because the board can possibly bounce back up after the wheels hit the pavement. It makes it much more difficult to land tricks and remain stable.

The trucks of skateboards and longboards are also different. Skateboards have small trucks, that stay underneath the board but longboards have wide trucks with a different design. Wide trucks provide more stability which is needed at high speeds.

If you put a longboard and skateboard side by side, you'll notice how flat the nose and tail of the longboard are. On a skateboard, you'll see more of a curve on its nose and tail to make it easier to land tricks and flips.

It should be no surprise that longboards are, of course, longer. They can be as long as 59 inches, while the typical skateboard is around 36 inches. Here's where it gets confusing: longboards also come in sizes as small as 28 inches long. If the length trips you up, just remember the key difference between the two is that longboards are flat and skateboards curve. So, if you see a flat, shorter board, it's probably just a short longboard.

Longboards are wider and longer than skateboards, are more flexible and easier to ride for beginners. Longboards have large soft wheels and skateboard have small hard wheels.

Big soft wheels are great for riding but are more bouncy compared to hard wheels. This means if you do an ollie (jump) for example, the board is more likely to bounce back up. This makes landing a trick unstable and more chances of landing primo (both feet on the side of the deck).

Skateboards have smaller trucks, longboards have wider trucks and have a different design. Wider trucks provide more stability which you need at higher speeds. Smaller trucks make a board more agile which is needed for ollies and flips.
question_src: 为什么这些天有这么多人选择长板上的长板？他们更容易骑吗？有什么好处？
pos_context_title_src: Longboard vs滑板 - 优点，缺点和差异 -  Boardcoast（www.boardcoast.com）
长板与滑板（www.redbull.com）
长板与滑板 - 相似性和差异| skateboardershq（www.skateboardershq.com）
pos_context_src:
长板通常比滑板更长且更宽。它们也有不同类型的车轮。长板有较大的柔软轮毂，而滑板则具有小的硬车轮。长板也更加灵活，并且往往更容易为初学者骑行。

长板上的柔软的车轮非常适合骑行，在高速上滚动裂缝和小碎片，但它们比硬轮弹跳。通常，在执行技巧时，您不想使用软轮，因为在车轮撞到人行道后，板可能会弹回。它使降落技巧和保持稳定更加困难。

滑板和长板的卡车也不同。滑板有小型卡车，可以留在板下方，但长板的卡车具有不同的设计。宽的卡车提供了更高的稳定性，在高速上需要。

如果您将长板和滑板并排放置，您会注意到长板的鼻子和尾巴的平坦。在滑板上，您会在鼻子和尾巴上看到更多的曲线，以使其更容易降落和翻转。

当然，长板的时间更长也就不足为奇了。它们的长度可能长达59英寸，而典型的滑板约为36英寸。这是令人困惑的地方：长板的尺寸也很小至28英寸。如果长度将您的行程往上走，请记住两者之间的关键区别是长板是平坦的，滑板曲线。因此，如果您看到一个较短的板，那可能只是一小段长板。

长板比滑板更宽，更长，更容易为初学者骑行。长板有大型柔软的轮子，滑板有小的硬轮。

大型柔软的车轮非常适合骑行，但与硬轮相比，弹性更大。这意味着，如果您进行Ollie（跳跃），则板更有可能反弹。这使得登陆是一个不稳定的捣蛋，并且有更多的降落机会（两脚都在甲板的侧面）。

滑板有较小的卡车，长板有更宽的卡车，并且设计不同。更宽的卡车提供了更高的稳定性，您需要以更高的速度。较小的卡车使板更敏捷，这是Ollies和Flips所需的。

question_en: Why can Parrots talk? Can they only repeat what people say, or can they formulate their own thoughts and vocalize them sometimes?
pos_context_title_en: Why Do Parrots Talk? (www.audubon.org)
Why Do Parrots Talk? (www.audubon.org)
How and why do parrots talk? Best talking parrot and teaching your parrot to talk (www.exoticdirect.co.uk)
How and why do parrots talk? Best talking parrot and teaching your parrot to talk (www.exoticdirect.co.uk)
Do Parrots Understand What They Say? - My Animals (myanimals.com)
Do Parrots Understand What They Say? - My Animals (myanimals.com)
pos_context_en: Parrots are vocal learners, meaning they grasp sounds by hearing and then imitating them. Although several other bird species can discern and repeat sounds, parrots are the pros.

For parrots, words may have some associations but not complex meanings, says Wright. “But they are very attuned to the context in which we use [words], and so I think that often fools people a little bit.”
Parrots talk by modifying the air that flows over the syrinx to make sounds. The syrinx is located where the trachea splits into the lungs.
Pssitacines (the parrot family) and Passerines (the song bird families) use their voices to warn, to court, to communicate with their nestlings and to fight to defend a territory.
The syrinx is a bony box made up of fused and widened rings. The vibratory membranes and the division of the trachea, which helps form the bronchi, are found inside it.

So, the challenges that Alex was able to carry out are proof that parrots do understand what they say. Contrary to what we may think, they’re not just randomly repeating what they hear in exchange for a treat.
question_src: 为什么鹦鹉可以说话？他们只能重复人们所说的话，还是可以表达自己的想法并有时会发声？
pos_context_title_src: 为什么鹦鹉说话？ （www.audubon.org）
为什么鹦鹉说话？ （www.audubon.org）
鹦鹉如何以及为什么说话？最好的会说话的鹦鹉和教您的鹦鹉说话（www.exoticdirect.co.uk）
鹦鹉如何以及为什么说话？最好的会说话的鹦鹉和教您的鹦鹉说话（www.exoticdirect.co.uk）
鹦鹉是否了解他们说的话？ - 我的动物（Myanimals.com）
鹦鹉是否了解他们说的话？ - 我的动物（Myanimals.com）
pos_context_src: 鹦鹉是声乐学习者，这意味着他们通过听到然后模仿它们来掌握声音。尽管其他几种鸟类可以辨别和重复的声音，但鹦鹉是专业人士。
赖特说，对于鹦鹉来说，单词可能具有一些关联，但含义却不复杂。 “但是它们非常适合我们使用[单词]的背景，因此我认为这常常会愚弄别人。”
鹦鹉通过修改流过Syrinx以发出声音的空气来交谈。 Syrinx位于气管分裂为肺部的地方。
pssitacines（鹦鹉家族）和雀形（The Passerines）（歌曲Bird家族）用他们的声音警告，法庭，与他们的雏鸟进行交流并为捍卫领土而战。
Syrinx是一个由融合和宽阔的环组成的骨盒。在其中发现了振动膜和气管的分裂，有助于形成支气管。
因此，亚历克斯能够实现的挑战证明了鹦鹉确实了解他们说的话。与我们可能的想法相反，他们不仅在随机重复他们听到的内容以换取零食。

question_en: Why do Women typically play softball rather than baseball in the U.S.?
pos_context_title_en: Why Can’t American Women Play Baseball? (www.thedailybeast.com)
Why not let girls play baseball instead of softball? (www.carolinacoastonline.com)
Will Women Play Major League Baseball? (And Not Just on TV) (www.nytimes.com)
pos_context_en:
However, like so many advancements for U.S. women during World War II, baseball later ceased to be a professional option. “In the 1950s, we shoved women out of everything,” Ring said. “We have this unfortunate decade for women in American history. It’s a decade when women are sent back into the home.”


With the women’s liberation movement and Title IX, sports reemerged in the 1970s for women, but baseball did not. “Baseball never turned a corner and opened the doors to women,” said Ring.


Indeed, there’s evidence there was a concerted effort to keep girls out of baseball. In 1972, the national Little League organization threatened to revoke the charter of a team in Hoboken, New Jersey, because they allowed 12-year-old Maria Pepe to play. The National Organization for Women took on the case and successfully sued to allow for Pepe and other girls to be able to try out. In response to the pressure, Little League created Little League Softball.

When Title IX, the 1972 law that required equal funding to both male and female sports teams, finally appeared, women were given fair ground on nearly every sport.


Baseball was not on that list, though. Instead, the law dictated that the school must provide an equivalent sport, and in that case, it was softball. Thus, schools were within their right to deny girls who were interested in baseball as long as a softball team was provided.


Since then, women all over the country, and now the world, have fought for the chance to play on their school’s baseball team. Some have succeeded, and most have failed, but none have made a serious impact.

Women’s baseball is not a high school sport in the United States, although it is in other nations, like Canada and Japan. In this country, girls are directed to softball, which is a women’s sport at the high school and collegiate level, Dr. Ring says.


“If a girl here wants to play baseball, she almost has to play with the boys and the pressure to switch from baseball to softball can be overwhelming,” she says. “People will tell her, you’re missing out on college scholarships” and may also suggest that she is hurting both her body and possibly male opponents’ egos if she sticks with hardball.


Playing elite baseball also can be profoundly lonely for a woman, says Ms. Hudek, the Bossier Parish college player and one of the most successful young female pitchers of recent years.
question_src: 为什么女性通常在美国打垒球而不是棒球？
pos_context_title_src: 美国女性为什么不能打棒球？ （www.thedailybeast.com）
为什么不让女孩打棒球而不是垒球？ （www.carolinacoastonline.com）
女子会打大联盟吗？ （不仅在电视上）（www.nytimes.com）
pos_context_src:
但是，就像第二次世界大战期间美国妇女的许多进步一样，后来棒球不再是专业选择。 “在1950年代，我们将妇女从所有事物中脱颖而出，”林说。 “我们为美国历史上的妇女提供了这个不幸的十年。这是妇女被送回家中的十年。”


随着妇女解放运动和第IX冠军，体育在1970年代为妇女重新出现，但棒球没有。林说：“棒球从未转过角，向女性打开大门。”


确实，有证据表明，有一致的努力使女孩脱离棒球。 1972年，国家小联盟组织威胁要撤销新泽西州霍博肯市一支团队的宪章，因为他们允许12岁的玛丽亚·佩佩（Maria Pepe）参加比赛。国家妇女组织采取了此案，并成功起诉允许Pepe和其他女孩能够尝试。为了应对压力，小联盟创造了小联盟垒球。

当Title IX（1972年的法律都需要为男性和女运动队提供同等资金）时，几乎每项运动都为妇女提供了公平的基础。


不过，棒球不在该名单上。取而代之的是，法律规定学校必须提供同等的运动，在这种情况下，这是垒球。因此，只要提供垒球队，学校就在否认对棒球感兴趣的女孩的权利之内。


从那时起，全国各地的女性，现在是全世界的妇女一直为他们的学校棒球队打球而战。有些人成功了，大多数人都失败了，但没有人会产生严重的影响。

尽管在加拿大和日本等其他国家，女子棒球不是美国的一项高中运动。 Ring博士说，在这个国家，女孩被指向垒球，这是高中和大学层面的女性运动。


她说：“如果这里的一个女孩想打棒球，她几乎必须和男孩一起玩，从棒球转换为垒球的压力可能是压倒性的。” “人们会告诉她，您错过了大学奖学金”，也可能暗示她会伤害自己的身体，甚至可能会伤害男性对手的自负，如果她坚持坚硬。


老板教区大学球员，近年来最成功的年轻女性投手之一哈德克女士说，对女人的比赛精英棒球也可能非常孤独。

question_en: Why does 'quick sand' make you sink and where does the sand go?
pos_context_title_en: Will Quicksand Really Kill You? (thescienceexplorer.com)
Quicksand. The science behind the properties of Quicksand. (www.zigya.com)
Quicksand. The science behind the properties of Quicksand. (www.zigya.com)
pos_context_en:
In fact, studies have found it is impossible to be completely submerged in quicksand because humans are less dense than quicksand and a person would only sink to their chest before they begin to float.


But what can make quicksand deadly is its ability to trap and hold unsuspecting victims.


Quicksand occurs when fine sediment such as clay, sand, silt, or other grainy soil becomes saturated with water, typically from a subterranean source. Often these traps are found near the periphery or edge of natural water sources. Often the sand on top may appear solid, but with the added pressure of a footstep, the sand will mix with the water beneath it forming a thick sludge.

Objects in the quicksand sink to the level at which the weight of the object is equal to the weight of the displaced soil/water mix and the submerged obje ct floats due to its buoyancy. The density of quicksand is 2 g/ml which is about twice that of a human body (1 g/ml), Thus, a human should sink only half way in (till the waist line), in case he/she does not struggle. Even objects with a higher density than quicksand will float on it—until they move.

The sand particles get displaced and the animal/human sinks in it. Objects in liquefied sand sink to the level at which the weight of the object is equal to the weight of the displaced soil/water mix. Since Quicksand has a density twice than that of human, thus a person is usually trapped to their waist.


As the weight of the organism becomes equal to that of the displaced quicksand, the liquefaction process stops and the sand eventually forms a semi-solid bed again. The denser sand grains hold the animal tight, preventing it from escaping.
question_src: 为什么“快速沙子”会让您下沉，沙子去了哪里？
pos_context_title_src: Quickss并真的会杀死您吗？ （thescienceexplorer.com）
流沙。 Quicksand属性背后的科学。 （www.zigya.com）
流沙。 Quicksand属性背后的科学。 （www.zigya.com）
pos_context_src:
实际上，研究发现，不可能完全淹没在速度中，因为人类比Quicksand的密度较少，并且一个人在开始漂浮之前只会沉入胸口。


但是，可以使快速和致命的方法陷入困境并抓住毫无戒心的受害者的能力。


当粘土，沙子，淤泥或其他颗粒状土壤等细小的沉积物（通常是从地下来源）饱和时，就会发生速度。通常，这些陷阱在天然水源的外围或边缘附近发现。通常，顶部的沙子可能看起来很固体，但是随着脚步的添加压力，沙子会与其下面的水混合在一起，形成厚厚的污泥。
速度中的物体将物体重量等于流离失所的土壤/水混合物的重量以及由于其浮力而淹没的OBJE CT浮子的水平。速度的密度为2 g/ml，大约是人体的两倍（1 g/ml），因此，如果他/她不挣扎，人类应该只沉入一半（直到腰线）。即使是比速度较高的物体，也会漂浮在其上 - 直到它们移动。

沙子颗粒被移位，动物/人沉入其中。液化的砂粒中的物体，到物体重量等于流离失所的土壤/水混合物的水平。由于Quicksand的密度是人的密度的两倍，因此一个人通常被困在腰上。


随着生物体的重量等于流离失所的速度和液化过程，液化过程停止，沙子最终再次形成半固定床。浓密的沙粒将动物紧紧固定，以防止其逃脱。

question_en: How did they work out the mass of the comet Phillae landed on?
pos_context_title_en: The tech behind the Rosetta comet chaser: From 3D printing to solar power to complex mapping - TechRepublic (www.techrepublic.com)
(www.vanderbilt.edu)
JimsAstronomy: Using Calculus to determine the mass of a comet (jdetrick.blogspot.com)
pos_context_en: To land on the comet, the ESA had to figure out the best way to orbit Rosetta around it. Rosetta has to be in front of the comet for the best light conditions from the sun. Using high-resolution digital images collected from several cameras on the spacecraft, including a wide angle lens, and scientific cameras to help map the area, the team generated a triangular orbit pattern around the comet. The challenge is now to figure out the gravitational pull of the comet. A pyramid shape allows them to better receive and analyze that data, eventually figuring out the density and mass of the comet.

What is the mass of a comet?


Let's assume the comet is a sphere with a radius of 5 km. Then the volume of this comet is


> V = 4/3 pi R^3= 500 km^3= 5 x 10^17 cm^3


Assuming a density of 1 gm/cc, typical for water ice, then this comet would have a total mass of 5 x 10^17 gm = 5 x 10^14 kg.

- The comet was 2,000 meters long. We can use Calculus to calculate the volume of the comet by measuring the radius at each point along its length then summing up (integrating) an infinite number of areas of circles with each radius over the entire length.
question_src: 他们是如何弄清楚菲利亚彗星降落的？
pos_context_title_src: Rosetta Comet Chaser背后的技术：从3D打印到太阳能到复杂映射-TechRepublic（www.techrepublic.com）
（www.vanderbilt.edu）
Jimsastronomy：使用微积分来确定彗星的质量（jdetrick.blogspot.com）
pos_context_src: 要降落在彗星上，ESA必须弄清楚围绕它的Rosetta的最佳方法。罗塞塔（Rosetta）必须在彗星前，才能获得太阳的最佳光条件。使用从航天器上的几个摄像机（包括广角镜）和科学摄像机收集的高分辨率数字图像来帮助绘制该区域，团队在彗星周围产生了三角形轨道图案。现在的挑战是找出彗星的引力。金字塔形状使他们能够更好地接收和分析数据，最终确定彗星的密度和质量。

什么是彗星的质量？


假设彗星是半径为5 km的球体。那么这个彗星的体积是


> v = 4/3 pi r^3 = 500 km^3 = 5 x 10^17 cm^3


假设密度为1 gm/cc，典型的水冰，那么该彗星的总质量为5 x 10^17 gm = 5 x 10^14 kg。
- 彗星长2,000米。我们可以使用微积分来计算彗星的体积，通过测量每个点的半径沿其长度，然后将（集成）在整个长度上汇总（集成）无限数量的圆地区域。

question_en: can weather or storms actually be controlled or man made? If so, to what extent and how?
pos_context_title_en: Can we control the weather? (science.howstuffworks.com)
New World War: Weather Warfare (www.newworldwar.org)
pos_context_en:
Finally, scientists had found a way to control the weather -- at least in the lab. For the next 30 years, researchers and entrepreneurs across the world began applying the principles developed by Langmuir, Schaefer and Vonnegut to real-world cloud seeding. They flew airplanes into the clouds, releasing their own clouds of silver iodide as they went, or fired artillery shells filled with silver iodide into clouds. In some cases, these weather modifiers were trying to produce rain in drought-afflicted areas, mitigate hail damage by preventing hailstones from growing so large, or disperse fog banks around airports. Many proprietors of this new technology made audacious claims about their cloud seeding services. Unfortunately, hard science could never substantiate the claims. If anything, rigorous experimentation seemed to suggest that cloud seeding barely worked or, worse, didn't work at all.

Still, enough tantalizing evidence has accumulated over the years to keep interest in weather modification alive. For example, research conducted in South Africa and Mexico has shown that seeding warm rain clouds with salt particles -- what is known as hygroscopic seeding -- is more effective than seeding cold rain clouds with silver iodide. And Chinese scientists believe they have mastered cloud seeding to such a degree that they can guarantee a certain day will be rainy or sunny, like say the opening ceremony of the 2008 Summer Olympics in Beijing, as this related article describes.

A precision lightning strike with synthetic lightning is also possible. The 2005 book, Weapons Grade: How Modern Warfare Gave Birth to Our High-Tech World, mentioned that artificial lightning had been accomplished using lasers. One reportedly had a range of about 200 meters, but could possibly be extended to about 2 miles. The 1997 Weather Wars: Pentagon Plans Weather as a Weapon article by the New York Times noted that the US Air Force was considering using such lasers for lightning attacks.

The US Air Force itself referenced using controlled lightning strikes to attack its targets. The Tofflers suggested that lasers can even be used to cut holes in the ozone layer above the land of an adversary.

HAARP

According to this information, weather modification is possible using electromagnetic waves. In the US and other countries, large weapons platforms to accomplish this appear to have been created.2

One such weapon is known as the High Frequency Active Auroral Research Project (HAARP). In their book Angels Don’t Play This HAARP: Advances in Tesla Technology, Jeane Manning and Dr. Nick Begich refer to it as one of the most powerful multi-purpose weapons developed by the US military.
question_src: 天气或暴风雨实际上可以控制还是制造人？如果是这样，在多大程度上以及如何？
pos_context_title_src: 我们可以控制天气吗？ （science.howstuffworks.com）
新世界大战：气象战（www.newworldwar.org）
pos_context_src:
最后，科学家至少在实验室找到了一种控制天气的方法。在接下来的30年中，世界各地的研究人员和企业家开始将Langmuir，Schaefer和Vonnegut开发的原则应用于现实世界中的云种子。他们将飞机飞入云层中，释放出自己的碘化银云，或者开了装满银碘化物的炮弹到云层中。在某些情况下，这些天气修饰符试图在干旱影响的地区降雨，从而防止冰雹生长如此大或在机场周围散布雾库来减轻冰雹损害。这项新技术的许多老板对他们的云种子服务提出了大胆的说法。不幸的是，硬科学永远无法证实主张。如果有的话，严格的实验似乎表明云种子几乎没有起作用，或者更糟的是根本没有起作用。

尽管如此，多年来，已经积累了足够的诱人证据，以使人们对天气修改的兴趣保持兴趣。例如，在南非和墨西哥进行的研究表明，用盐颗粒播种温暖的雨云（所谓的吸湿播种）比用碘化银播种冷雨云更有效。中国科学家认为，他们已经掌握了云播种的程度，以至于他们可以保证某天会下雨或晴天，就像这篇相关文章所描述的那样，北京2008年夏季奥运会的开幕式。

还可以通过合成闪电进行精确的雷击。 2005年的书《武器等级：现代战争如何诞生了我们的高科技世界》，提到人造闪电是使用激光完成的。据报道，一个人的射程约为200米，但可能会延伸到约2英里。 1997年的天气战：五角大楼计划天气作为《纽约时报》的武器文章指出，美国空军正在考虑使用此类激光器进行闪电袭击。

美国空军本身使用受控雷击来攻击其目标。太妃糖建议激光甚至可以用来在对手土地上方的臭氧层中切下孔。

哈普

根据这些信息，使用电磁波可以改变天气。在美国和其他国家，似乎已经创建了实现这一目标的大型武器平台。2

一种这样的武器被称为高频主动极光研究项目（HAARP）。在他们的著作《天使》中，没有扮演这一HAARP：特斯拉技术的进步，让·曼宁（Jeane Manning）和尼克·贝吉奇（Nick Begich）博士将其称为美国军方开发的最强大的多用途武器之一。

question_en: If you put water bottles under a frozen lake when the outside temperate is below freezing will the bottles not freeze because the water under a lake is still liquid
pos_context_title_en: Temperature And Ice - Lake Scientist (www.lakescientist.com)
When and how do lakes freeze over? - RMBEL (www.rmbel.info)
How does a lake freeze? (whyfiles.org)
pos_context_en: What happens under the ice of lakes? Water under the ice typically stays very cold, but above freezing. Most lakes that form ice at the surface stay at about 4^oC most of the winter months.

As you all know, water freezes at 32 degrees Fahrenheit. That doesn’t mean, however, when the air temp reaches 32 the lakes freeze. Water is a great insulator and good at holding heat, which is why the lake temperature doesn’t fluctuate much day to day like the air does. Therefore, below freezing temperatures are needed for a week or more to form ice on a large lake.

As winter sets in, lakes lose energy to the atmosphere, and water near the surface cools, becomes more dense, and sinks. Warmer, less dense water under the surface will rise to replace this surface water. When the entire lake reaches 40 F, the surface water cools further, dropping below 40 F. Because this water is now less dense than the surrounding water, it will stay on the top and continue to cool.


Once the surface water falls to 32 F, it freezes. The freezing then spreads downward into the lake and the ice thickens. Unless the lake is very shallow, you will find liquid water below the ice. This deeper water is about 40 F
question_src: 如果您将水瓶放在冷冻的湖下，而外部温带在冰点以下，则瓶子不会冻结，因为湖下的水仍然是液体
pos_context_title_src: 温度和冰 - 湖科学家（www.lakescientist.com）
湖泊何时以及如何冻结？ -rmbel（www.rmbel.info）
湖如何冻结？ （whyfiles.org）
pos_context_src: 在湖泊的冰下会发生什么？冰下的水通常保持很冷，但在冰冻之上。大多数在地表上形成冰的湖泊在大约4^OC的大部分时间里。
众所周知，水以华氏32度冻结。但是，这并不意味着当空气温度达到32时，湖泊冻结。水是一个很好的绝缘子，擅长保持热量，这就是为什么湖温每天不像空气那样每天波动的原因。因此，在一个星期或更长时间以下的冰点温度以下才能在大湖上形成冰。

随着冬季的到来，湖泊会失去大气的能量，表面冷却，变得更加密集，下沉。较温暖的地面下的量较少，较少的水将升高以取代这种地表水。当整个湖泊达到40 f时，地表水会进一步冷却，下降到40 f以下。由于现在的水比周围水的密度较低，因此它将保持在顶部并继续冷却。


一旦地表水降至32 F，它就会冻结。然后冻结向下蔓延到湖中，冰变厚了。除非湖很浅，否则您会在冰下找到液态水。这种更深的水约为40 f

question_en: Why is it cheaper for employers to have their workers get compensatory time instead of overtime pay?
pos_context_title_en: Compensatory Time Off Vs. Overtime Pay | FedSmith.com (www.fedsmith.com)
Comp time vs. overtime – What you need to know (www.insperity.com)
Comp time vs. overtime – What you need to know (www.insperity.com)
Federal Employees - Compensatory Time Off (www.opm.gov)
pos_context_en: Comp time for the Federal employee is one paid hour off for each hour of irregular or occasional overtime that has been worked.
The Fair Labor Standards Act (FLSA) governs what employers must do under federal law.

The legal requirements of each state also factor into what options might be available to you as an employee or as the employer.


Violations of the law relating to overtime pay can be viewed as wage theft and an attempt at evading the law, which can be accompanied by high fines and prison time in some states.

Agencies may require that an FLSA exempt employee (as defined at 5 U.S.C. 5541(2)) receive compensatory time off in lieu of overtime pay for irregular or occasional overtime work, but only for an FLSA exempt employee whose rate of basic pay is above the rate for GS-10, step 10.
question_src: 为什么雇主让工人获得补偿时间而不是加班费会更便宜？
pos_context_title_src: 补偿时间休息加班费| fedsmith.com（www.fedsmith.com）
Comp Time vs.加班 - 您需要知道的内容（www.insperity.com）
Comp Time vs.加班 - 您需要知道的内容（www.insperity.com）
联邦雇员 - 补偿时间休假（www.opm.gov）
pos_context_src: 联邦雇员的计算时间是每小时不规则或偶尔加班的一小时休息时间。
《公平劳动标准法》（FLSA）管辖雇主根据联邦法律必须做的事情。

每个州的法律要求还考虑了您作为雇员或雇主可以使用的选项。


违反与加班费有关的法律的行为可以看作是盗窃工资，并试图逃避法律，在某些州可以伴随着高罚款和监狱时间。
机构可能要求FLSA豁免雇员（定义为5 U.S.C. 5541（2））获得补偿时间，以代替不规则或偶尔的加班工作加班费，但仅对FLSA免税员工的基本工资率高于GS-10的基本工资税率高于GS-10的费用。

question_en: Clock Speeds and/vs Cores in computers
pos_context_title_en: CPU Speed: What Is CPU Clock Speed? | Intel (www.intel.com)
CPU Speed: What Is CPU Clock Speed? | Intel (www.intel.com)
CPU Speed: What Is CPU Clock Speed? | Intel (www.intel.com)
Do I Need Lots of Cores or a Faster CPU Clock Speed? | Create Pro (create.pro)
Do I Need Lots of Cores or a Faster CPU Clock Speed? | Create Pro (create.pro)
Do I Need Lots of Cores or a Faster CPU Clock Speed? | Create Pro (create.pro)
pos_context_en: The CPU multiplier (sometimes called the “CPU ratio”) is multiplied against the CPU Base Clock (or BCLK) to determine the processor’s clock speed. A CPU multiplier of 46 and a base clock of 100 MHz, for example, results in a clock speed of 4.6GHz.

CPU clock speed is a good indicator of your processor’s performance. Though applications like video editing and streaming are known to rely on multi-core performance, many new video games still benchmark best on CPUs with the highest clock speed.
A CPU with a clock speed of 3.2 GHz executes 3.2 billion cycles per second.
A core is a single processing unit, multi-core processors have multiple processing units. So a dual-core 3.0GHz processor has two processing units each with a clock speed of 3.0GHz.
Multi-threading is the ability of an application or operating system to utilise multiple cores for processing.
Hyper-threading is a proprietary Intel technology that allows a single core to split into a virtual and a logical core and share workload between the two.
question_src: 计算机中的时钟速度和/vs芯
pos_context_title_src: CPU速度：什么是CPU时钟速度？ |英特尔（www.intel.com）
CPU速度：什么是CPU时钟速度？ |英特尔（www.intel.com）
CPU速度：什么是CPU时钟速度？ |英特尔（www.intel.com）
我需要很多核心还是更快的CPU时钟速度？ |创建Pro（create.pro）
我需要很多核心还是更快的CPU时钟速度？ |创建Pro（create.pro）
我需要很多核心还是更快的CPU时钟速度？ |创建Pro（create.pro）
pos_context_src: CPU乘数（有时称为“ CPU比率”）乘以CPU基本时钟（或BCLK）来确定处理器的时钟速度。例如，CPU乘数为46，基本时钟为100 MHz，使时钟速度为4.6GHz。
CPU时钟速度是您处理器性能的良好指标。尽管众所周知，视频编辑和流媒体等应用程序依赖于多核性能，但许多新的视频游戏仍然在CPU上以最高的时钟速度为基础。
时钟速度为3.2 GHz的CPU每秒执行32亿个周期。
核心是单个处理单元，多核处理器具有多个处理单元。因此，双核3.0GHz处理器的时钟速度为3.0GHz。
多线程是应用程序或操作系统利用多个内核进行处理的能力。
超线程是一种专有的英特尔技术，它允许单个核心分为虚拟和逻辑核心，并在两者之间共享工作负载。

question_en: How do events in my dreams coincide with events that are happening in real life?
pos_context_title_en: Dreaming of the Future (www.psychologytoday.com)
pos_context_en:
Throughout history, people have believed that prophetic dreams can give us glimpses of future events. Is there any reason to believe such dreams are possible?


It would seem not. Most instances of a dream predicting a significant event in waking life are probably just coincidences. For example, people periodically dream of car crashes, so at some point, a person will dream of a car crash the night before actually getting in a car crash. That’s not prophecy, that’s just the law of averages. The claims people make about future-telling dreams are most likely to be fantasies, fabrications, or failures of causal reasoning.


That may be the safest position to take. It’s not the most scientific position, however, because it isn’t based on evidence, just a resolute skepticism. The actual evidence in support of anticipatory dreaming is not so easily dismissed and merits more serious attention than it typically receives.
question_src: 我梦中的事件如何与现实生活中发生的事件相吻合？
pos_context_title_src: 梦想未来（www.psychologytoday.com）
pos_context_src:
在整个历史上，人们都认为预言的梦想可以使我们了解未来的事件。有什么理由相信这样的梦想是可能的吗？


似乎不是。梦想中的大多数实例预测唤醒生活中的重要事件可能只是巧合。例如，人们会定期梦见车祸，因此在某个时候，一个人会梦想在实际撞车前一天晚上发生车祸。那不是预言，那只是平均定律。人们对未来梦想的说法最有可能是幻想，捏造或因果推理的失败。


这可能是最安全的位置。但是，这不是最科学的立场，因为它不是基于证据，而只是坚决的怀疑主义。支持预期梦的实际证据并不容易被驳回，比通常收到的更为严重的关注。

question_en: Why is the U.S. rail system so awful?
pos_context_title_en: The US is terrible at building high-speed rail — here's why (www.cnbc.com)
The real reason the United States has no high-speed rail network (www.grunge.com)
The real reason the United States has no high-speed rail network (www.grunge.com)
pos_context_en:
China has the world's fastest and largest high-speed rail network — more than 19,000 miles, the vast majority of which was built in the past decade.


Japan's bullet trains can reach nearly 200 miles per hour and date to the 1960s. They have moved more than 9 billion people without a single passenger casualty.


France began service of the high-speed TGV train in 1981 and the rest of Europe quickly followed.


But the U.S. has no true high-speed trains, aside from sections of Amtrak's Acela line in the Northeast Corridor. The Acela can reach 150 mph for only 34 miles of its 457-mile span. Its average speed between New York and Boston is about 65 mph.


California's high-speed rail system is under construction, but whether it will ever get completed as intended is uncertain.

High-speed rail isn't just achievable: It already exists. However, as with anything else in the U.S. today, the biggest obstacle in the way of American high-speed rail is politics. Speeding up the Acela Express, for example, would require billions in federal funding, according to Fortune. Good luck with that in today's polarized environment. Meanwhile, the political squabbles that have faced California's bullet train ambitions are now legendary, and not in a good way. While the concept of connecting the Golden State's biggest cities via bullet train is brilliant, Vox says the planning has been horrendous, between the addition of pointless and expensive stops, rushed construction, and bad financial decisions. The political battles got even nastier in 2019, when the Trump administration pulled $929 million in federal grants for California's high-speed rail, according to MSN.

The U.S. automobile obsession is an obstacle for high-speed rail dreams, according to Forbes, because cultural mores impact funding decisions. The U.S. has higher car ownership rates than other nations, so these countries are far more open to the idea of putting higher taxes on vehicles to cut demand — sometimes to the point of taxing purchasers an additional 150 percent on the car's base price. You think a tax like that would ever fly in the U.S.? Not in this lifetime.
question_src: 为什么美国铁路系统如此糟糕？
pos_context_title_src: 美国在建造高铁方面非常糟糕 - 这就是为什么（www.cnbc.com）
美国没有高铁网络（www.grunge.com）的真正原因
美国没有高铁网络（www.grunge.com）的真正原因
pos_context_src:
中国拥有世界上最快，最大的高速铁路网络 - 超过19,000英里，其中绝大多数是在过去十年中建造的。


日本的子弹列车每小时可以达到近200英里，到1960年代。他们搬走了超过90亿人，没有一次乘客伤亡。


法国于1981年开始为高速TGV火车提供服务，欧洲其他地区很快随之而来。


但是，除了东北走廊的Amtrak线路以外，美国没有真正的高速火车。 ACELA只能在其457英里跨度的34英里处达到150英里 /小时。它在纽约和波士顿之间的平均速度约为65英里 /小时。


加利福尼亚州的高铁系统正在建设中，但是它是否会按预期完成。

高铁不仅可以实现：它已经存在。但是，与当今美国的其他任何事情一样，美国高速铁路的最大障碍是政治。据《财富》报道，例如，加快Acela Express将需要数十亿美元的联邦资金。在当今两极分化的环境中，祝您好运。同时，面对加利福尼亚子弹列车野心的政治争吵现在是传奇的，而且不是很好。虽然通过子弹列车连接黄金州最大的城市的概念是出色的，但Vox说，在增加毫无意义和昂贵的停靠站，急速建设和不良财务决策之间的计划是可怕的。根据MSN的说法，2019年，特朗普政府为加利福尼亚州的高速铁路收取了9.29亿美元的联邦赠款，这场政治战争变得更加艰难。
根据福布斯的说法，美国汽车的痴迷是对高铁梦的障碍，因为文化氛围会影响资金决策。美国拥有比其他国家的汽车所有权率更高，因此，这些国家更开放的想法是将更高的税收征收以减少需求的税收 - 有时使购买者的基本价格征税150％。您认为这样的税收会在美国持续吗？不在这一生中。

question_en: Why does HTTPS/SSL need a certificate to do secure transmission, while SSH does not?
pos_context_title_en: HTTPS: What is a SSL Certificate and Why Do You Need One? | Redwood Valley Technical Solutions Web Design (rvtechsolutions.com)
SSH vs SSL | Top 8 Differences and Comparisons You Should Learn (www.educba.com)
pos_context_en:
[Image: SSL Certificate Secure Browsing]Both HTTPS and SSL are in place to ensure your website is trustworthy and responsible. Through approving your webpage, your audience knows that they are more or less protected when browsing or buying from your page.

If you’re not familiar with HTTPS and SSL, you’ll want to brush up on what they mean and what they include. Let’s begin by taking a look at what HTTPS and SSL stand for.

HTTPS stands for Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure. HTTPS is the secure version of HTTP, meaning that the communication between your visitor and your website is secure and encrypted.

There are a number of benefits to having an HTTPS website over a standard HTTP, especially if your visitor is frequently entering detailed or sensitive information when they visit your site. If your customer needs to enter credit card information or other personal information, you’ll want to have an HTTPS page.

Having an HTTPS shows your visitor that you’re a valid company, so they don’t need to be worried about entering credit card information to make a purchase online. The information they do enter will become encrypted, so it cannot be stolen or intercepted.

Your HTTPS website can establish a stronger level of trust with your customer. When they know that their information is protected, they’ll be more likely to purchase from your company over your competition.

## What is SSL?

SSL, which stands for Secure Socket Layer, works with your HTTPS website to protect your customer’s information and privacy. SSL, which may also be called TLS, or Transport Layer Security, is the encryption communication that your HTTPS website will use to encrypt the information a customer or client puts into your website.

Both SSH and SSL are public-key cryptography protocols that create a secure, confidential exchange of data and connection across the Internet. Let’s discuss some of the major key differences:

 1. Usually, SSH uses Port 22, whereas SSL uses Port 443. 2. SSH uses a username/password authentication process to establish a secure connection, whereas SSL does not consider it. 3. SSH is based on network tunnelling, whereas SSL is based on certificates. 4. SSL is used for securely transmitting critical information like credit cards and banking. Whereas SSH is used for securely executing commands across the Internet. 5. SSL is used for encrypting communication between browser and server. On the other hand, SSH is used for encrypting communication between two computers over the Internet. 6. In SSL, the communication is authenticated via the private-key/public-key pair. Whereas in SSH, the communication is authenticated via private-key/public-key pair or username/password pair. 7. Technically, SSH is for securing computer networks, whereas SSL is for securing online data transfers. 8. SSL generally (except exceptions) uses X.509 digital certificates for server and client authentication processes, whereas SSH does not. 9. Another major difference is that SSH has more built-in functionality than SSL. It helps in enabling users to log in to a server and execute commands remotely, whereas SSL does not have this functionality. To achieve this functionality, you need to pair it with another protocol like HTTP, FTP.
question_src: 为什么HTTPS/SSL需要证书来进行安全传输，而SSH则没有？
pos_context_title_src: https：什么是SSL证书，为什么需要一个证书？ | Redwood Valley技术解决方案Web Design（RVTechsolutions.com）
SSH vs SSL |您应该学习的前8个差异和比较（www.educba.com）
pos_context_src:
[图片：SSL证书安全浏览] HTTPS和SSL都可以确保您的网站值得信赖和负责。通过批准您的网页，您的受众知道他们在浏览或从页面上购买时或多或少受到保护。

如果您不熟悉HTTPS和SSL，则需要仔细研究它们的含义和所包含的内容。首先，看看HTTP和SSL的代表。

HTTPS代表超文本传输​​协议安全。 HTTPS是HTTP的安全版本，这意味着您的访问者和网站之间的通信是安全和加密的。

与标准HTTP相比，拥有HTTPS网站有很多好处，尤其是如果您的访客在访问您的网站时经常输入详细信息或敏感信息时。如果您的客户需要输入信用卡信息或其他个人信息，则需要拥有HTTPS页面。

拥有HTTPS向您的访客展示您是一家有效的公司，因此他们无需担心输入信用卡信息即可在线购买。他们输入的信息将被加密，因此不能被盗或拦截。

您的HTTPS网站可以与您的客户建立更强的信任水平。当他们知道自己的信息受到保护时，他们更有可能在您的公司中从公司购买。

##什么是SSL？

代表安全套接字层的SSL与您的HTTPS网站合作，以保护客户的信息和隐私。 SSL（也可以称为TLS或运输层安全性）是您的HTTPS网站使用的加密通信来加密客户或客户将信息输入您网站的信息。

SSH和SSL都是公钥加密协议，可以在整个Internet上创建安全，机密的数据和连接。让我们讨论一些主要关键区别：

 1。通常，SSH使用端口22，而SSL使用端口443。2。SSH使用用户名/密码身份验证过程来建立安全连接，而SSL不考虑它。 3。SSH基于网络隧道，而SSL基于证书。 4。SSL用于安全地传输关键信息，例如信用卡和银行业务。而SSH用于在整个Internet上安全执行命令。 5。SSL用于加密浏览器和服务器之间的通信。另一方面，SSH用于通过Internet上两台计算机之间的通信进行加密。 6。在SSL中，通信通过私钥/公钥对进行身份验证。而在SSH中，通信是通过私钥/公共键对或用户名/密码对进行身份验证的。 7。从技术上讲，SSH用于保护计算机网络，而SSL用于保护在线数据传输。 8。SSL通常（例外除外）使用X.509用于服务器和客户端身份验证过程的数字证书，而SSH则没有。 9。另一个主要区别是SSH比SSL具有更多的内置功能。它有助于使用户登录到服务器并远程执行命令，而SSL没有此功能。为了实现此功能，您需要将其与其他协议（例如HTTP，FTP）配对。

question_en: Why do mobile websites have a "click here to continue reading" button?
pos_context_title_en: Designing “Read More” And “Continue Reading” Links — Smashing Magazine (www.smashingmagazine.com)
How “Hiding” Content Behind a Read More Button Impacts SEO (www.dealer.com)
Read More Button - How to Add, Best Practices & SEO Impacts - SEOptimer (www.seoptimer.com)
pos_context_en:
Before we present the showcase, let’s understand why “Read more” links are so important. They are important for several reasons, most importantly because they allow designers to compress content on the home page. By compressing content, you fit more content in less space. This means that readers can scan headlines more quickly and that you can fit more information above the fold.


More after jump! Continue reading below ↓


Also, “Read more” links allow website administrators to more easily track the most popular content. Designers who put entire articles on the home page may make it difficult for website administrators to track the most popular articles and understand what users want to see.


The third and probably most practical reason for having “Read more” links on a website is money. Websites that monetize traffic understand that the more their readers click on links, the more likely they will look at and click on advertisements. “Read more” links can double or even triple the number of page views a website receives, making it more attractive to advertisers.

At this year’s SMX Advanced in Seattle I asked Google’s Gary Illyes if “hiding” content behind a Read More button affects websites’ SEO.


His answer wasn’t surprising considering Google’s stance on user experience. This practice, which essentially directs users to click a button/link that says Read More or Read On to view the full content, does have an effect on sites’ SEO, including auto retailers using Dealer.com Websites. Specifically, Google does not index content hidden behind these buttons on desktop sites.

The ‘read more ‘ button comes in handy for every webmaster. The button is versatile and has many uses, for example, it can be used to truncate content so that only a part is displayed. It is also used to toggle between showing and hiding content, for example when a site hides content and wants you to subscribe in order to read the rest.
question_src: 为什么移动网站有“单击此处继续阅读”按钮？
pos_context_title_src: 设计“更多”和“继续阅读”链接 -  Smashing Magazine（www.smashingmagazine.com）
阅读更多按钮后面的“隐藏”内容如何影响SEO（www.dealer.com）
阅读更多按钮 - 如何添加，最佳实践和SEO影响 -  Seoptimer（www.seoptimer.com）
pos_context_src:
在提出展示柜之前，让我们了解为什么“阅读更多”链接如此重要。它们的重要性很重要，最重要的是，因为它们允许设计人员在主页上压缩内容。通过压缩内容，您可以在更少的空间中拟合更多内容。这意味着读者可以更快地扫描头条新闻，并且您可以在折叠上方贴上更多信息。


跳跃后更多！继续在下面阅读↓


此外，“阅读更多”链接允许网站管理员更轻松地跟踪最受欢迎的内容。将整个文章放在主页上的设计师可能会使网站管理员很难跟踪最受欢迎的文章并了解用户想要看到的内容。


在网站上具有“阅读更多”链接的第三个也是最实际的原因是金钱。货币化流量的网站了解，读者单击链接的越多，他们就越有可能查看并单击广告。 “阅读更多”链接可以将网站收到的页面视图数量增加甚至三倍，从而使其对广告客户更具吸引力。

在今年的SMX Advanced中，我问Google的Gary Illyes，是否“隐藏”阅读按钮后面的内容会影响网站的SEO。


考虑到Google对用户体验的立场，他的回答并不奇怪。这种练习本质上指示用户单击一个说明更多阅读或阅读以查看完整内容的按钮/链接，确实会影响网站的SEO，包括使用ealerer.com网站的自动零售商。具体来说，Google不会在桌面站点上隐藏在这些按钮后面的索引内容。
每个网站管理员的“读取更多”按钮都派上用场。该按钮具有通用性，并且具有许多用途，例如，它可用于截断内容，因此只显示一个零件。它也用于在显示和隐藏内容之间切换，例如，当一个站点隐藏内容并希望您订阅以阅读其余内容时。

question_en: Why do most doors have a two stage locking mechanism instead of one?
pos_context_title_en: Multipoint Locking Systems Explained (brennancorp.com)
Do I Need a Multipoint Lock for My Door? (www.pellabranch.com)
pos_context_en:
The extra locking points strengthen your home’s security by providing a tighter seal along the length of the door, top-to-bottom. This compression also makes the door more weathertight than a standard door, which makes it more energy efficient.


With a standard locking system, your primary lock is in the center, usually a single deadbolt. In that case, the top and bottom of the door don’t have integrated locks which leaves the door more vulnerable to a break-in.

Older door locks with similar functionality could only be secured from the inside and required you to turn a lock at each point. Modern multipoint door locks are easier to operate. The three-point locking system involves just one lock mechanism and dual-action deadbolts. So all three deadbolts respond to the same key turn — no need to stretch or bend down to lock different parts of the door.
question_src: 为什么大多数门都有两个阶段的锁定机制而不是一个锁定机制？
pos_context_title_src: 多点锁定系统解释（brennancorp.com）
我的门需要一个多点锁吗？ （www.pellabranch.com）
pos_context_src:
额外的锁定点可以通过沿着门的长度提供更紧密的密封，从而增强了房屋的安全性。这种压缩还使门比标准门更具智能，这使其更有效。


使用标准锁定系统，您的主要锁位于中心，通常是单个螺栓。在这种情况下，门的顶部和底部没有集成的锁，这使门更容易受到闯入的影响。
具有相似功能的较旧的门锁只能从内部固定，并要求您在每个点上锁定。现代的多点门锁更容易操作。三点锁定系统仅涉及一个锁定机构和双动锁定螺栓。因此，所有三个僵局都对相同的钥匙响应 - 无需伸展或弯曲以锁定门的不同部分。

question_en: Why is eating burnt food bad for you?
pos_context_title_en: Acrylamide (www.niehs.nih.gov)
Acrylamide Questions and Answers (www.fda.gov)
Does Burnt Food Cause Cancer? | Dana-Farber Cancer Institute (blog.dana-farber.org)
Heterocyclic Amine - an overview (www.sciencedirect.com)
pos_context_en: When certain foods are cooked at high temperatures, sugars, such as glucose and fructose, can react with the free amino acid, asparagine, to form acrylamide. Acrylamide forms as part of a chemical reaction, known as the Maillard reaction, which contributes to the aroma, taste, and color of cooked foods. Acrylamide is one of the hundreds of chemicals that can form during the Maillard reaction.

Acrylamide caused cancer in animals in studies where animals were exposed to acrylamide at very high doses. In 2010, the Joint Food and Agriculture Organization/World Health Organization Expert Committee on Food Additives (JECFA) concluded that acrylamide is a human health concern, and suggested additional long-term studies. FDA experts participated in the evaluation and provided data from new research studies on acrylamide risk.

When it comes to cooking meat, there are two different chemicals that occur when meat is cooked.


Polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs) are formed when fat and juices drip onto flames while frying, baking, or grilling meat. Heterocyclic amines (HCAs) are generated from reactions between molecules including amino acids and sugars.


[Image]


HCAs form when meat is exposed to high temperatures for a prolonged period of time; the longer the exposure, the more HCAs are formed. Microwaving meat briefly before cooking at a high temperature reduces the time the meat needs to be cooked, and therefore less HCAs are produced. Although some studies how burnt, fried, or barbecued meat is associated with higher risk of certain cancers in lab tests, the connection between charred food and increased cancer risk is not proven for certain.

HCAs form when amino acids and creatine react at high cooking temperatures and are formed in greater quantities when meats are overcooked or blackened. Seventeen different HCAs resulting from the cooking of muscle meats have been identified, which may pose human cancer risk.


HCAs develop a powerful carcinogenic potential when activated by cytochrome P450 1A2-mediated oxidation of the amino group, which is followed by acetylation or sulfation to form direct-acting reactive mutagens that attack key elements in DNA. When fed to rats, several of these HCAs can induce cancer of the mammary glands, colon, and pancreas.
question_src: 为什么吃燃烧的食物对您有害？
pos_context_title_src: 丙烯酰胺（www.niehs.nih.gov）
丙烯酰胺的问题和答案（www.fda.gov）
燃烧的食物会导致癌症吗？ | Dana-Farber癌症研究所（blog.dana-farber.org）
杂环胺 - 概述（www.sciencedirect.com）
pos_context_src: 当某些食物在高温下烹饪时，糖（例如葡萄糖和果糖）可以与游离氨基酸（天冬酰胺）反应形成丙烯酰胺。丙烯酰胺形成是化学反应的一部分，称为Maillard反应，该反应有助于烹饪食物的香气，味道和颜色。丙烯酰胺是在Maillard反应过程中可能形成的数百种化学物质之一。
丙烯酰胺在动物以非常高剂量暴露于丙烯酰胺的研究中引起了癌症。 2010年，粮食和农业组织/世界卫生组织食品添加剂专家委员会（JECFA）得出结论，丙烯酰胺是人类健康的关注，并提出了其他长期研究。 FDA专家参与了评估，并提供了有关丙烯酰胺风险的新研究数据。

在烹饪肉方面，煮肉时会发生两种不同的化学物质。


当脂肪和果汁在炸，烘烤或烤肉时滴落到火焰上时，会形成多环芳烃（PAHS）。杂环胺（HCA）是由包括氨基酸和糖在内的分子之间的反应产生的。


[图像]


肉类长时间暴露于高温时，HCAS形式；暴露时间越长，形成的HCA就越多。在高温下烹饪之前，短暂的微波肉减少了需要烹饪的时间，因此产生的HCA少。尽管一些研究在实验室测试中燃烧，油炸或烧烤肉与某些癌症的较高风险有关，但烧焦食品与癌症风险增加之间的联系并不能确定。

当氨基酸和肌酸在高烹饪温度下反应时形成HCA，并且当肉被过度煮熟或变黑时形成更大的数量。已经确定了肌肉肉烹饪导致的17种不同的HCA，这可能会带来人类癌症的风险。


当通过细胞色素P450 1A2介导的氨基氧化激活时，HCA会产生强大的致癌潜力，然后将乙酰化或硫酸化形成直接作用的反应性诱变，从而攻击DNA中的关键元素。当喂给大鼠时，其中几个HCA可以诱导乳腺，结肠和胰腺的癌症。

question_en: Explain: (to Americans): Canadian Election today
pos_context_title_en: Elections | The Canada Guide (thecanadaguide.com)
Elections | The Canada Guide (thecanadaguide.com)
5 steps to understanding Canada’s election (www.politico.com)
5 steps to understanding Canada’s election (www.politico.com)
5 steps to understanding Canada’s election (www.politico.com)
pos_context_en:
Canadian government is divided into three levels: federal, provincial, and local, and Canadians elect the politicians who run all three.


* A national election, sometimes called a federal election or a Canadian general election, is an election to pick members of the House of Commons.
* A provincial election picks people to sit in one of the 10 provincial parliaments.
* A municipal election chooses city-level officials like the mayor,

The Constitution of Canada says any citizen of Canada over the age of 18 is eligible to vote in a federal, provincial or local election. This includes Canadians living abroad, who can vote via absentee ballots at overseas embassies and consulates, and even Canadians in prison.

Trudeau, Scheer and the leaders of other national parties will tour the country, making the case for their party. At the same time, incumbents and challengers will compete in the 338 separate elections for Commons seats.
One member of Parliament is chosen for each Commons seat. (Canada's other chamber, the Senate, is not elected.)
If the winning party wins 169 seats or fewer, they will form a minority government.
question_src: 解释：（对美国人）：今天的加拿大大选
pos_context_title_src: 选举|加拿大指南（thecanadaguide.com）
选举|加拿大指南（thecanadaguide.com）
了解加拿大选举的5个步骤（www.politico.com）
了解加拿大选举的5个步骤（www.politico.com）
了解加拿大选举的5个步骤（www.politico.com）
pos_context_src:
加拿大政府分为三个层次：联邦，省和地方，加拿大人选举了经营三个的政客。


*全国大选，有时被称为联邦大选或加拿大大选，是挑选下议院议员的选举。
*省选举将人们坐在十个省议会之一中。
*市政选举选择像市长这样的城市官员，
加拿大宪法说，18岁以上的加拿大公民有资格在联邦，省级或地方选举中投票。这包括居住在国外的加拿大人，他们可以通过在海外大使馆和领事馆的缺席选票中投票，甚至加拿大人入狱。
特鲁多（Trudeau），谢尔（Scheer）和其他民族党的领导人将巡回该国，为他们的政党辩护。同时，现任者和挑战者将参加Commons席位的338个单独选举。
每个公地席位选择一个议会议员。 （加拿大的另一个会议厅，参议院，未当选。）
如果获胜党赢得169个席位或更少的席位，他们将组成少数派政府。

question_en: Hacking JLaw's phone was a sex crime but hacking then publicly shaming Ashley Madison users is not. Please explain!
pos_context_title_en: Hacker sentenced to prison for role in Jennifer Lawrence nude photo theft (www.theguardian.com)
Hacking Laws and Punishments - FindLaw (www.findlaw.com)
Why The Stolen Ashley Madison Data Is (Legally) Fair Game For The Internet (consumerist.com)
Why The Stolen Ashley Madison Data Is (Legally) Fair Game For The Internet (consumerist.com)
pos_context_en: George Garofano, 26, was accused of illegally hacking the private Apple iCloud accounts of 240 people, including Hollywood stars as well as average internet users, allowing their nude photos and private information to be spread around the internet.

Hacking is broadly defined as the act of breaking into a computer system. Hacking isn't always a crime as "ethical hacking" occurs when a hacker is legally permitted to exploit security networks. In other words, it's when a hacker has the appropriate consent or authorization. However, hacking crosses the criminal line when a hacker accesses someone's computer system without such consent or authority.

As CNN and Motherboard have both explained, Ashley Madison is filing DMCA requests left and right, claiming that as they own copyright on the leaked materials, it is unlawful to redistribute or look at them. The claims are basically the same sort of takedown requests a film studio would file to get as-yet-unreleased movies pulled offline.


Whether they have a leg to stand on with those claims, however, is another story.


Motherboard delved into a lengthy explanation about what’s copyrightable and what’s not after Ashley Madison challenged a tweet from one of their staff writers. The TL;DR version of the law, which is important here, is that you can copyright original works, but not lists of facts.

Parts of the Ashley Madison data dump are copyrightable information. The source code for their websites, for example, is original work. Any advertising copy they published on their sites is, likewise, original to them. (And the source code for all of Avid Life’s sites has, indeed, been leaked, so they have some grounds there.)


But a big fat *.csv file full of data? That’s a set of facts, and as such, not a thing that is subject to being copyrighted.


Plenty of other information Ashley Madison has or had access to is also subject to copyright: anything the users write on their profiles, and the images they share. But the account-holders — all 30-odd million of them — are the ones who own that material. That’s been how leaked or stolen material has been successfully taken down before, for example when celebrities’ private photos were stolen from their phones in 2014. Google and other companies did comply with requests to take the images down, because those individuals owned their images and had grounds to request their removal.


You Can’t Put The Toothpaste Back In The Tube
As much as Ashley Madison and all its users wish it were not so, not only is the data probably not subject to copyright claims… but also even if it were, the media can still talk about it as much as they want.


The hackers absolutely broke laws when they stole information from inside Avid Life Media. But media who report on the information are not breaking laws. National security concerns aside (that’s covered by different law), the press can basically run with any information given to them innocently, even if the person giving it to them obtained it illegally.
question_src: 黑客jlaw的电话是一次性犯罪，但黑客却公开羞辱了阿什利·麦迪逊（Ashley Madison）的用户。请解释一下！
pos_context_title_src: 黑客因在Jennifer Lawrence Nude Photo Theft（www.theguardian.com）中的角色而被判处监狱。
黑客法律和惩罚-FindLaw（www.findlaw.com）
为什么被盗的阿什利·麦迪逊（Ashley Madison）数据（法律上）是互联网的公平游戏（Consumerist.com）
为什么被盗的阿什利·麦迪逊（Ashley Madison）数据（法律上）是互联网的公平游戏（Consumerist.com）
pos_context_src: 26岁的乔治·加罗法诺（George Garofano）被指控非法黑客攻击240人的私人苹果iCloud帐户，包括好莱坞明星以及普通的互联网用户，允许他们的裸照和私人信息在互联网上传播。
黑客被广泛定义为闯入计算机系统的行为。黑客并不总是犯罪，因为当法律允许黑客利用安全网络时，就会发生“道德黑客”。换句话说，这是黑客拥有适当同意或授权的时候。但是，当黑客未经这种同意或权威而访问某人的计算机系统时，黑客越过了犯罪线。

正如CNN和主板都解释的那样，阿什利·麦迪逊（Ashley Madison）正在向左右提出DMCA请求，声称他们拥有泄漏材料的版权，重新分配或查看它们是非法的。这些索赔基本上是电影工作室将要提出的同样的撤销请求，以使尚未发行的电影离线。


然而，他们是否有腿可以站起来，这是另一个故事。


主板对Ashley Madison向他们的一位员工作家提出了一条推文后，深入探究了可版权的冗长解释。在这里很重要的法律的TL; DR版本是您可以版本的原创作品，但不能列出事实。

Ashley Madison数据转储的一部分是可版权的信息。例如，其网站的源代码是原始工作。他们在网站上发布的任何广告副本对他们来说都是原始的。 （确实，所有狂热生活网站的源代码确实已经泄漏，因此他们在那里有一些理由。）


但是一个充满数据的大脂肪 *.csv文件？这是一组事实，因此，这不是受版权保护的事情。


阿什利·麦迪逊（Ashley Madison）拥有或可以访问的许多其他信息也符合版权：用户在其个人资料上写的任何内容以及他们共享的图像。但是，帐户持有人 - 其中全部有300万人 - 是拥有该材料的人。这就是在2014年名人的私人照片被偷走的私人照片之前成功删除的泄漏或被盗的材料。Google和其他公司确实遵守了将图像放下的请求，因为那些人​​拥有他们的图像并有基础来要求将其移走。


你不能把牙膏放回管子里
尽管阿什利·麦迪逊（Ashley Madison）及其所有用户都希望并非如此，但不仅数据可能不受版权要求的约束……而且即使是，媒体仍然可以随心所欲地谈论它。


当黑客从狂热的生活媒体中偷走信息时，黑客绝对会违反法律。但是报告信息的媒体并没有违反法律。除了国家安全问题（这是不同法律所涵盖的），新闻界基本上可以无辜地提供任何信息，即使给他们的人非法获得了。

question_en: Who starts chain letters ("Pass this on or you'll die within the next seven months" or "Send this to ten people within the next seven hours and you'll receive good luck for the next year") and how do they benefit from them? Who profits?
pos_context_title_en: Chain letters (www.units.miamioh.edu)
Chain letters (www.units.miamioh.edu)
Chain letters (www.units.miamioh.edu)
Chain letters (www.units.miamioh.edu)
Chain letters (www.units.miamioh.edu)
pos_context_en: Chain letters are letters that direct the recipient to send out multiple copies so that circulation increases. These letters can be sent via the postal service or by e-mail. The distribution of chain letters through the postal service has neared extinction yet computers have extended the lifespan of this particular type of communication.

They may tell a joke, promise good fortune, threaten you with bad luck, or inform you of another's tragedy or misfortune. These letters often promise the recipients some type of reward if they pass the message on to others. When sent through e-mail, there is usually a long list of previous recipients, but no address or name to identify the original sender. This could possibly be a problem because there is no way to check the authenticity of the letter. Although it is possible for the information to have some truth, chain letters may also contain information that is completely false.

Why do people send chain letters? There are several known reasons to explain the chain letters' popularity. One reason is that it is a great source for obtaining new e-mail addresses. These addresses may lead to new contacts. This tactic can be considered an example of the "free-rider effect". The "free-rider effect" involves depending on others to collectively complete a task. The original senders may, for some reason, decide that they need to obtain e-mail addresses. In order to find these addresses, the senders will initiate a chain letter and rely on the recipients to pass the letter to others. Each time the letter is sent to someone new, their address will be added to the list of recipients and the original senders will have obtained the addresses they wanted while exerting little effort.

Some people send chain letters simply to see how far it will go or to harass another person. There may be times when someone decided that they want to damage a person's or organization's reputation. This is obviously the case with the Neiman-Marcus Cookie Recipe discussed in the Legend of and on the Internet section. Some people are out to get money, and may be successful, through pyramid schemes distributed through an e-mail chain.

Many times these chain letters make promises to the recipient in exchange of sending the message to other people. The recipients may adhere to the senders' request because they believe that sending the message to others will contribute to their good luck. "This belief is an example of self-fulfilling prophecy. Self-fulfilling prophecy is when an originally false social belief leads to its own fulfillment."

连锁信（www.units.miamioh.edu）

pos_context_src: 链信件是指导收件人发送多个副本的字母，以使循环增加。这些信件可以通过邮政服务或电子邮件发送。通过邮政服务的链信件的分布已经接近灭绝，但计算机延长了这种特定类型的通信的寿命。
他们可能会开玩笑，保证好运，厄运威胁您，或告诉您他人的悲剧或不幸。这些字母通常会向收件人提供某种类型的奖励，如果将信息传递给其他人。通过电子邮件发送时，通常会有一长串以前的收件人列表，但没有地址或名称可以识别原始发件人。这可能是一个问题，因为没有办法检查字母的真实性。尽管信息有可能具有一些真相，但链信也可能包含完全错误的信息。

人们为什么要发送连锁信？有几个已知的理由来解释链信的受欢迎程度。原因之一是它是获得新电子邮件地址的好来源。这些地址可能会导致新的联系。这种策略可以被视为“自由骑士效应”的例子。 “自由式效果”涉及取决于其他人以共同完成任务。原始发件人可能由于某种原因决定他们需要获得电子邮件地址。为了找到这些地址，发件人将发起链信件，并依靠收件人将信件传递给他人。每次将信件发送给新人时，他们的地址都会添加到收件人列表中，而原始发​​件人将在付出很少的精力时获得他们想要的地址。
有些人发送链信件只是为了查看它将走多远或骚扰另一个人。有时可能有人决定损害一个人或组织的声誉。显然，在互联网部分和互联网部分中讨论的Neiman-Marcus cookie食谱就是这种情况。有些人通过通过电子邮件链条分发的金字塔计划来赚钱，并可能成功。
很多时候，这些连锁信向收件人承诺，以交换向其他人发送消息。收件人可以遵守发件人的请求，因为他们认为向他人发送消息会有助于他们的好运。 “这种信念是自我实现预言的一个例子。自我实现的预言是最初有虚假的社会信念导致自己的实现的时候。”

pos_context_en: But Room-mania is only just warming up. James Franco is currently directing and starring in The Disaster Artist, a behind-the-scenes comedy about the making of the film. Also in the cast are three of Franco’s fellow Oscar nominees, Bryan Cranston, Sharon Stone and Jacki Weaver. What this means is that some of the best actors in the movie industry are currently pretending to be its worst.

it had a budget of $6 million. Despite looking as if it was thrown together one weekend in a friend’s flat, it was actually shot over six months on a Los Angeles soundstage, and the tales of how Wiseau burnt through all that cash are essential to its mythos. Believe it not, he adapted The Room from a 500-page novel; he shot it on film and on digital video simultaneously; he replaced the crew four times and the cast three times

Somehow, he simply doesn’t see anything wrong with The Room, as much as he enjoys participating in its mockery. “Long story short,” he says, using one of his favourite expressions, “I never called The Room the worst movie ever. That’s number one. Number two, I never called it a cult. But when people call it a cult I think it’s complimentary.”
As a director, I have to feel realism from actors, and they can't be plastic.

它的预算为600万美元。尽管看起来一个周末在一个朋友的公寓里被扔到了一个周末，但实际上是在洛杉矶的声音舞台上拍摄了六个月的时间，以及有关维沃（Wiseau）如何通过所有现金燃烧的故事对其神话至关重要。不相信，他从一本500页的小说中改编了房间。他同时在电影和数字视频上拍摄了它。他四次取代了船员，演员三次

question_en: How to seeing eye dogs know exactly where their owners want them to go.
pos_context_title_en: How do Guide Dogs work? (chicagolighthouse.org)
Good to know (www.blindenhundeschule.ch)
pos_context_en:
Q: How do dog guides know where to go when traveling?


A: This is a team effort between the dog and its owner. The owner knows where and how he wants to get to a certain place, and he or she is responsible for telling the dog through verbal and hand signals. Directions include forward, left and right. When at a street crossing, the owner is responsible for judging when it is safe to cross based on the sound of the cars, and should then command the dog to begin crossing. Intelligent disobedience is when a dog refuses to cross the street because it is unsafe to do so, even when the owner has commanded it to go forward.

Guide dogs don’t know where the visually impaired or blind person wants to go. The guide dog owner communicates via vocal cues which direction the dog needs to follow. Therefore, guide dog owners need to have a good sense of direction and to keep a map of their route in mind.
question_src: 如何看到眼狗确切地知道主人想要他们去哪里。
pos_context_title_src: 导犬如何工作？ （chicagolighthouse.org）
很高兴知道（www.blindenhundeschule.ch）
pos_context_src:
问：狗向导如何知道旅行时要去哪里？


答：这是狗与其主人之间的团队努力。主人知道他想在哪里以及如何到达某个地方，他或她负责通过口头和手势告诉狗。指示包括向前，左右。当在街道交叉处时，所有者负责根据汽车的声音进行安全穿越时进行判断，然后命令狗开始越过。聪明的不服从是在狗拒绝过马路的时候，因为这样做是不安全的，即使主人命令它向前走。
导盲犬不知道视力障碍或盲人想要去哪里。导狗主人通过声音提示进行通信，狗需要遵循哪个方向。因此，指导狗主人需要具有良好的方向感，并记住其路线的地图。

pos_context_en:
## Metal Gear Solid


FOXHOUND rebels and takes over a compound in the Alaska known as Shadow Moses. Once again Solid Snake has to come out of retirement to deal with the bad guys. Luckily this time BIG BOSS is actually dead, but unluckily they have a new METAL GEAR: REX. They also have a couple hostages including Roy Campbell's niece (I never was 100% why all of FOXHOUND except Campbell revolted). You sneak in and save the hostages, fight Revolver Ocelot, who seems to think this is the 1800s, get saved by a creepy Cyborg Ninja, who no one knows and may or may not be a friend and have a short love story with Meryl Silverberg (Campbell's niece).

## Metal Gear Solid 3: Snake Eater


After the cliff hanger at the end of MGS2, in true Metal Gear Solid fashion, MGS3 has nothing to do with it. Instead, MGS3 is a prequel. You're Naked Snake (see how hard was that) who was trained under The BOSS a hero of WW2 who also defects to the Russians. You infiltrate their base, learn about an Illuminati-esque organization The Philosophers who may or may not be dead, meet a young Revolver Ocelot, find out The BOSS didn't defect and is only on a mission, beat up everybody, save the world (but in secret), get dubbed the boss of all bosses: BIG BOSS, and finally get to have sex with a hot chick. Oh and Ocelot works for the CIA under the call sign ADAM... no clue why.

> So apparently after MGS2, when no one decided to do anything about the Patriots they took over the world and made it all about war, either your economy was based on war or your country was in a war. But since it's a modern war its all about the genetic engineered soldiers and nano machines. Controlled, of course, by a system called Sons of the Patriots or SOP (weren't these the guys trying to hide their existance?); and Liquid/Ocelot is out hijack it. So sure enough, Roy Campbell asks Snake to come out of retirement, one more time, and deal with Liquid/Ocelot. Hey, it could be worse. You could be Raiden again...

##金属齿轮固体


狐狸猎犬叛军，接管了阿拉斯加的一个名为“影子摩西”的化合物。坚实的蛇必须退休才能与坏人打交道。幸运的是，这次Big Boss实际上已经死了，但不幸的是，他们有一个新的金属装备：Rex。他们也有几个人质，包括罗伊·坎贝尔（Roy Campbell）的侄女（我从来都不是100％，为什么除了坎贝尔（Campbell）反击外，所有狐狸猎犬都为何）。您偷偷摸摸地拯救了人质，战斗左轮手枪，他似乎认为这是1800年代，被一个令人毛骨悚然的半机械人忍者拯救了，他没有人知道并且可能不是朋友，并且与梅丽尔·西尔弗伯格（Meryl Silverberg）（坎贝尔的侄女）有一个短暂的爱情故事。

## Metal Gear Solid 3：蛇食者


在MGS2末端的悬崖吊架之后，以真正的金属装备固体方式，MGS3与它无关。相反，MGS3是前传。您是赤裸裸的蛇（看看那是多么艰难），他在老板的训练下受过训练，这是第二次世界大战的英雄，他也陷入了俄罗斯人的叛逃。您渗透了他们的基础，了解一个光明的组织，哲学家可能会或可能不会死，与年轻的左轮手枪，发现老板没有缺陷，只有在执行任务，殴打每个人，拯救世界，秘密地拯救世界（但在秘密），被所有老板配音，大老板：大老板，最终与一只热的小鸡做爱。哦，Ocelot在呼号亚当（Adam）下为中央情报局（CIA）工作...不知道为什么。

>很明显，在MGS2之后，当没有人决定对爱国者队采取任何行动时，他们接管了世界并就战争做了一切，要么您的经济是基于战争，要么是您的国家正在战争中。但是，由于这是一场现代战争，因此关于基因工程士兵和纳米机器的全部。当然，由一个称为爱国者或SOP的儿子的系统控制（这些家伙试图掩盖自己的存在？）；液体/ocelot劫持了它。因此，罗伊·坎贝尔（Roy Campbell）要求蛇再退休，再一次与液体/ocelot打交道。嘿，可能会更糟。您可能会再次被袭击...

question_en: How do our minds estimate the passage of time?
pos_context_title_en: Your Brain Has 2 Clocks (www.scientificamerican.com)
Physics explains why time passes faster as you age (qz.com)
A stopwatch on the brain's perception of time (www.theguardian.com)
pos_context_en:
Neuroscientists believe that we have distinct neural systems for processing different types of time, for example, to maintain a circadian rhythm, to control the timing of fine body movements, and for conscious awareness of time passage. Until recently, most neuroscientists believed that this latter type of temporal processing – the kind that alerts you when you’ve lingered over breakfast for too long – is supported by a single brain system. However, emerging research indicates that the model of a single neural clock might be too simplistic. A new study, recently published in the Journal of Neuroscience by neuroscientists at the University of California, Irvine, reveals that the brain may in fact have a second method for sensing elapsed time. What’s more, the authors propose that this second internal clock not only works in parallel with our primary neural clock, but may even compete with it.


Past research suggested that a brain region called the striatum lies at the heart of our central inner clock, working with the brain’s surrounding cortex to integrate temporal information.

According to Bejan—who reviewed previous studies in a range of fields on time, vision, cognition, and mental processing to reach his conclusion—time as we experience it represents perceived changes in mental stimuli. It’s related to what we see. As physical mental-image processing time and the rapidity of images we take in changes, so does our perception of time. And in some sense, each of us has our own “mind time” unrelated to the passing of hours, days, and years on clocks and calendars, which is affected by the amount of rest we get and other factors.

It has also been shown that the cerebellum plays a key role in motor tasks requiring perception of implicit timing. Other parts of the brain may be involved in implicit-timing estimates: for example, the left parietal cortex, which manages intended movement, and the left premotor cortex, which plans and organises movement. Sometimes the right prefrontal cortex, usually involved in explicit-timing estimates, is activated for implicit estimates, for instance, when an event does not occur as soon as expected: a traffic light stays red for longer than foreseen. The brain updates its time forecasts, once again anticipating the interval.


In addition, "the regions of the brain involved differ depending on the context, particularly if the stimulus only lasts for a very short time, less than 200 milliseconds," says Coull. The visual cortex is activated when we estimate the duration of a visual stimulus. In the same way, the primary motor cortex comes into play when a timing estimate is associated with an action, whereas the auditory cortex has a part in estimating the length of a sound stimulus.


Above all, the brain's perception of time involves processes linked to memory and attention: witness the impression that time is passing more quickly when we are busy, or doing something amusing or exciting. Time flies even when we are in love. In contrast, a watched pot never boils. Minutes drag by when we are bored.
question_src: 我们的思想如何估计时间的流逝？
pos_context_title_src: 您的大脑有2个时钟（www.scientificamerican.com）
物理学解释了为什么随着年龄的增长，时间会更快地传播（QZ.com）
大脑对时间感知的秒表（www.theguardian.com）
pos_context_src:
神经科学家认为，我们有不同的神经系统来处理不同类型的时间，例如维持昼夜节律，以控制精美的身体运动的时机以及有意识地了解时间通道。直到最近，大多数神经科学家都认为，单一的大脑系统支持您在早餐过长的时间徘徊时提醒您的那种暂时性处理。但是，新兴的研究表明，单个神经时钟的模型可能太简单了。加州大学尔湾分校的神经科学家最近发表在《神经科学杂志》上的一项新研究表明，大脑实际上可能有第二种传达经过时间的方法。更重要的是，作者提出，第二个内部时钟不仅与我们的主要神经时钟平行，甚至可能与之竞争。


过去的研究表明，一个称为纹状体的大脑区域位于我们中央内钟的核心，与大脑周围的皮层合作以整合时间信息。
据贝扬（Bejan）称，他在时间，视觉，认知和心理处理中审查了以前的研究，以达到他的结论，但在我们经历时，它代表了心理刺激的变化。这与我们所看到的有关。随着身体心理图像的处理时间和我们对变化的图像的速度，我们对时间的看法也是如此。从某种意义上说，我们每个人都有自己的“思维时间”与时钟和日历上的小时，天和数年无关，这受我们得到的休息和其他因素的影响。

还已经表明，小脑在需要感知隐式时机的运动任务中起关键作用。大脑的其他部分可能参与了隐式定时估计：例如，管理预期运动的左顶壁皮层和计划和组织运动的左前前皮层。有时，通常参与显式定时估计的右前额叶皮层会被激活以进行隐式估计，例如，当事件未预期发生时：交通信号灯比预见的更长。大脑会更新其时间预测，再次预测间隔。


此外，“涉及大脑的区域取决于上下文，特别是如果刺激仅持续很短的时间，小于200毫秒的情况。”当我们估计视觉刺激的持续时间时，可激活视觉皮层。以同样的方式，当定时估计与动作相关时，主电动机皮层发挥作用，而听觉皮层则参与估计声音刺激的长度。


最重要的是，大脑对时间的看法涉及与记忆和注意力相关的过程：见证了当我们忙碌或做有趣或令人兴奋的事情时，时间会更快地过去。时间即使我们恋爱了。相比之下，一个看着的锅永远不会沸腾。我们无聊时拖延。

question_en: Why was the USS Enterprise CVN-65 decommissioned?
pos_context_title_en: USS Enterprise (CVN-65) (en.wikipedia.org)
USS Enterprise (CVN-65) (en.wikipedia.org)
USS Enterprise (CVN-65) (en.wikipedia.org)
pos_context_en:
USS Enterprise (CVN-65), formerly CVA(N)-65, is a decommissioned[14] United States Navy aircraft carrier. She was the first nuclear-powered aircraft carrier and the eighth United States naval vessel to bear the name. Like her predecessor of World War II fame, she is nicknamed "Big E". At 1,123 feet (342 m),[6][7] she is the longest naval vessel ever built. Her 93,284-long-ton (94,781 t)[5] displacement ranks her as the 12th-heaviest carrier, after the ten carriers of the Nimitz class and USS Gerald R. Ford. Enterprise had a crew of some 4,600 service members.[8]


The only ship of her class, Enterprise[15] was, at the time of inactivation, the third-oldest commissioned vessel in the United States Navy after the wooden-hulled USS Constitution and USS Pueblo.[16] She was inactivated on 1 December 2012,[17] and officially decommissioned on 3 February 2017,[18][19] after over 55 years of service.

Enterprise was the first nuclear-powered aircraft carrier to be decommissioned.[82] Naval enthusiasts requested that Enterprise be converted into a museum.[83][84] By 2012 this was deemed too expensive to make such an effort practical, in addition to the fact that the ship would need to be partially dismantled anyway to remove the eight reactors safely.[21] A petition was also set up for the next carrier to be named as the ninth USS Enterprise.[85]

The only ship of her class, Enterprise[15] was, at the time of inactivation, the third-oldest commissioned vessel in the United States Navy after the wooden-hulled USS Constitution and USS Pueblo.[16] She was inactivated on 1 December 2012,[17] and officially decommissioned on 3 February 2017,[18][19] after over 55 years of service.
